section.Subtitle: Summary
section.Paragraph: After joining the team, I took a pass to evaluate how well the current functionality met the needs of the users.

section.Subtitle: Product Opportunity
section.Paragraph: How can we make automations less confusing and support the continued asks of our power users so we are not limited.

section.Subtitle: Methods
section.Paragraph: I conducted contextual inquiry, surveys, dived into existing bugs and SRs, interviewed power users, looked at feature requets

section.Subtitle: Synthesis
section.Paragraph: From our research we identified two key pain points.
Bullets: - Users wanted to create complicated jobs. Lots of duplicativeness in how jobs were created and what jobs to create, Difficult to reference different parts of a job, no overview of a job existed,(reviewing of jobs created)

section.Subtitle: Jobs Modal
section.Paragraph: The onboarding flow was updated to provide users context on how many questions were involved, as well as decrease the number of questions asked upfront.

section.Subtitle: Jobs Table
section.Paragraph: The product information architecture was updated to better display the information in a manner that users would understand.

section.Subtitle: Results
section.Paragraph: While the initial solution sought to streamline our enrollment process, and we have successfully moved from a nine-step wizard to a one-step wizard. After talking to subject matter experts, I learned that the most important steps for users to interact with were in the last few steps where we were seeing less than 20% interaction. The original wizard was lengthy in order to prove users with a sense of customization but failed to actually encourage customization. Enrollment rates have increased by 60%. 20% of users are willingly engaging in customization.
